John, note that one complication in doing this is that you would lose
the continuity of the species numbers and sizes with current versions
of NEAT.  What should be done is that species numbers get recorded
such that they can be restored, and also the compat_thresh needs to be
remembered in the case of dynamic thresholding.  Otherwise, species
will be renumbered on each generation, and you will forget what your
threshold is.

So are you saying you intend to write NEAT in Perl or just modify an
existing NEAT and connect it to Perl?  Either way it's an interesting
idea, but is Perl fast enough to be the main body of NEAT?  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@h...> wrote:
> Here's what I'm thinking I want:
> 
> An executable that encapsulates the NEAT-specific functionality. 
For 
> example,
> 
> $ neat-gen <settings>.xml <in-pop>.xml <in-fit>.xml <out-pop>.xml 
> <out-phenotype>.xml
> 
> Why separate it out from the main experiment loop?  Because I want
the 
> experiment loop to be controlled by CGI scripts.  I want it to be 
> event-driven.  I want an experiment to be able to pick right up
where it 
> left off after a reboot or power outage.  Because my ultimate goal
is a 
> distributed NEAT that may take months to get anywhere... :(
> 
> Those of you with an existing NEAT implementation could probably
convert it 
> for use in this manner in about a half-hour, huh?  :)  And if you
are 
> willing to save me the effort, I wouldn't complain...
> 
> Otherwise, I'll probably build it in Perl, since that's the language
I'm the 
> most proficient in.  (YANI...yet another neat implementation.  :-) )
 Before 
> I begin, would any of you like to give me some tips or suggestions?
 Some 
> design suggestions that you perhaps wish you had thought of before
you 
> started?  Anything?  Thanks!
> 
> -- John
